channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Jordan, Ever Younger Syrian Brides
item.description: For many Syrian families in Jordan’s refugee camps, marrying girls off at younger ages is seen as necessary, but women’s advocates say that they are trading immediate dangers for longer-term ones.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Uganda Fears Terror Attack After Finding Militant Cell
item.description: The Ugandan authorities have uncovered a “terrorist cell” run by the Somali militant Islamist group the Shabab, which they said they believed was planning an imminent attack.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Putin Intent on Taking ‘All of Ukraine,’ Leader Says
item.description: Only the military backing of NATO can defend Ukraine, the prime minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, told a conference of security experts in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The Donetsk International Airport on Saturday, as shelling continued between pro-Russian forces and the Ukrainian military.

item.title: Struggling to Starve ISIS of Oil Revenue, U.S. Seeks Assistance From Turkey
item.description: The territory ISIS controls in Iraq produces thousands of barrels of oil that can fetch millions on the Turkish black market, and U.S. officials are leaning heavily on Turkey to take action.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Close to Deal, Rebels Fight Yemeni Troops
item.description: Clashes broke out in a northwestern district of Sana near a state television building when troops stopped a rebel truck loaded with weapons, military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Followers of the Houthi rebel group attended Friday prayers during a rally in Sana, the capital.

item.title: Air France-KLM Warns of Flight Cancellations as a Strike Looms
item.description: A dispute with pilots over the carrier’s planned expansion of a low-cost unit has the potential to disrupt the travel plans of tens of thousands of passengers.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Bracing for Change on Scotland’s Border, Whatever the Referendum Result
item.description: Polls show that the referendum on Scottish independence will be close, and people in England’s northernmost town fear that life will never be the same again — even if Scots vote to stay in the union.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Tourists posed for a photograph on the Scottish border in Berwick-Upon-Tweed, England, last weekend. Many of the city’s residents have Scottish roots.

item.title: Liberian President Pleads With Obama for Assistance in Combating Ebola
item.description: Liberia’s president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, warned that without American assistance, the Ebola epidemic could send the country into the civil chaos that enveloped it for two decades.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood Says Qatar Ousted Its Members
item.description: Other Persian Gulf monarchies, mainly Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, have been putting pressure on Qatar to stop supporting the group.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Obama Sees Iraq Resolution as a Legal Basis for Airstrikes, Official Says
item.description: The president has cited an earlier authorization by Congress as a basis for his campaign against ISIS.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: U.S. Scientists See Long Fight Against Ebola
item.description: The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is likely to last 12 to 18 months more and could infect hundreds of thousands, say scientists mapping its spread for the American government.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY
item.media:description: A woman in Monrovia, Liberia, passed a man believed to be infected with Ebola. Researchers say it could take 12 to 18 months to bring the epidemic under control.

item.title: Iran’s Participation in Meeting to Aid Iraq Is ‘Not Appropriate,’ Says Kerry
item.description: The French hosts of a meeting to coordinate assistance to the Iraqi fight against Islamist militants have not ruled out Iran’s attendance, but the United States is arguing against the country’s inclusion.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Ex-President of Haiti Put Under House Arrest
item.description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide was placed on house arrest in a corruption investigation, an order protested by his supporters whom claimed there was no provision in Haitian law for such a penalty.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Open Source: Professor’s Angry Tweets on Gaza Cost Him a Job
item.description: The University of Illinois rescinded a job offer to a professor over concerns about the tenor of his criticism of Israel’s Gaza offensive on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Rob Ford, Toronto Mayor, Withdraws Re-election Bid
item.description: Minutes after the announcement, a representative for Doug Ford, the mayor’s brother who is a City Council member, formally registered him as a mayoral candidate.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: U.S. Arms and Saudi Money Combine to Bolster Military’s Arsenal
item.description: The United States has delivered Hellfire missiles to the Lebanese Army and will also provide it with light aircraft, including an armed Cessna, the American ambassador to Lebanon, David Hale, said Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Embrace of Social Media Aids Flood Victims in Kashmir
item.description: Social media companies, government agencies and still-connected individuals have cooperated to help locate some 12,000 people amid the flooding and communications difficulties.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Distributing relief goods in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Friday. With telecommunications largely knocked out, social media has helped rescuers locate people.

item.title: Where a Sip of Whisky Usually Cures All, a Secession Vote Proves Bitter
item.description: As the referendum on Scotland nears, tensions are growing on Islay, where many residents worry their community will be deeply and enduringly fractured.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: At the Caol Ila distillery on Islay, a Scottish island. Its 3,000 residents are believed to be roughly evenly split over independence as a referendum nears.

item.title: U.S. and European Sanctions Take Aim at Putin’s Economic Efforts
item.description: The measures take aim at financial, defense and industrial companies at the vanguard of a push by the Russian leader to replace wild free-market capitalism with state-led development.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Detained, Beaten and Tortured by Separatists in Donetsk Ordeal
item.description: Extrajudicial detentions have become commonplace in eastern Ukraine, where one man says his brutal ordeal ended only when his abductors realized they might have the wrong man.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: “They stood in a circle kicking me. I would fall and they would yank me up and beat me againsaid Alexsandr.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Guilty of Culpable Homicide
item.description: Oscar Pistorius was found guilty of a charge equivalent to manslaughter in the shooting of Reeva Steenkamp, but he was granted bail and will remain free until sentencing procedures on Oct. 13.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Ian Paisley Dies at 88; Longtime Voice of Hard-Line Ulster Who Then Made Peace
item.description: The Protestant leader who vowed never to compromise with Irish Catholic nationalists accepted in his twilight a power-sharing agreement after decades of sectarian violence.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: Rift Emerges Before Vote in Sweden as Immigration Tests a Tradition of Openness
item.description: National elections will be held on Sunday, and the center-right government has lost some supporters to an anti-immigrant alternative.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CROUCH
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt of Sweden has decided to gamble re-election on embracing the country’s tradition of openness.

item.title: Truce Is Strengthening, Ukraine President Says
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko, who has been trying to generate a sense of momentum for a lasting cease-fire, also ruled out trying to take back Crimea by force.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Ebola Outpaces Global Response, W.H.O. Says
item.description: A doubling of the number of new cases in Liberia this week from the week before is of particular concern, the U.N. health agency said.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
